metadata.case_name: G. Gilda Textile Agency v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant is Messrs. G. Gilda Textile Agency, Vijayawada, an agent of several non-resident principals, on whose behalf it booked orders and dealt with the indents.

Agreements between non-resident principals and appellant contained in letters marked Exs. A-3, A-3a and A-3b; appellant appointed as indenting agent in Andhra Pradesh for cloth merchants residing and carrying on business outside Andhra Pradesh.

Appellant required to book orders and forward them to principals, receiving commission on sale of goods despatched to Andhra Pradesh; in some cases commission on orders booked by appellant, in others on all sales in territory.
Appellant did business in three categories: first, took delivery of goods, found buyers and delivered to buyers; held within Madras General Sales Tax Act, appellant liable, no question.

Second category: merely booked orders, forwarded to Bombay, principals sent goods with railway receipts through bank to purchasers in Andhra Pradesh; appellant's connection not sufficient to constitute it a 'dealer', omitted from turnover, no dispute.

Third category: goods sold by outside dealers to buyers in State; appellant booked orders, received railway receipts from outside principal, handed them to buyers, sometimes collected and transmitted amounts to principal.
Matter relates to levy of sales tax on appellant's turnover for years 1954-55 and 1955-56.
Appellant did not produce any correspondence with non-resident principals or covering letters sent with railway receipts.
Tribunal held railway receipts must have been endorsed by sellers in favour of appellant or in blank, deemed appellant a dealer under s.14-A, liable to tax.
High Court judgment and order dated September 19, 1958, in Tax Revision Cases Nos. 62 and 63 of 1956.
Period covered by Sales Tax Validation Act, 1956, no question under Constitution.

High Court finding: non-resident principals carrying on business of selling in Andhra Pradesh as they took out railway receipts in their own names, manifesting intention to remain owners and retain control; sales completed in Andhra Pradesh.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant comes within s. 14-A of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939, as agent of non-resident and liable to tax as a dealer in respect of the third category of transactions.

petitioner_arguments.text: Non-resident principals were not carrying on the business of selling in Andhra Pradesh; appellant not liable under s.14-A as first condition not fulfilled.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mahadayal Premchandra v. Commercial Tax Officer, Calcutta; s.14-A Madras General Sales Tax Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-section (2) of s.14-A connected to opening part; tax leviable on turnover relating to business of non-resident carried on by non-resident in taxable territory.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.14-A(2) Madras General Sales Tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant, after securing orders, received railway receipts from sellers, handed to buyers, collected consideration and transmitted to sellers; sales took place in State either on behalf of appellant or principals.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.14-A Madras General Sales Tax Act

court_reasoning.text: High Court finding that non-resident principals carrying on business of selling in Andhra Pradesh stands; if principals took railway receipts in own names, sales completed in Andhra Pradesh.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-resident principals doing business of selling in Andhra Pradesh.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant admitted agent through whom business carried on; liable under s.14-A fictionally as dealer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agent assessed in respect of business of non-resident irrespective of turnover minimum.

court_reasoning.text: Mahadayal Premchandra distinguished on its own facts; no finding there applicable here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Findings on facts of one case cannot apply to another.

court_reasoning.text: Once finding that non-resident principal carried on business of selling in Andhra Pradesh and appellant agent, rest follows.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court right in upholding levy.

holdings.text: Appellant comes within four corners of s.14-A in relation to third category transactions; liable to tax as agent of non-resident deemed dealer.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahadayal Premchandra v. Commercial Tax Officer, Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Agent liability under similar section in Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act; turned on facts where principal not selling in taxable territory.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for revisions, deems agent of non-resident as dealer liable to tax on business of non-resident in State.

statutes_cited.name: Sales Tax Validation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Covers the period involved, no constitutional question.

outcome.summary: Appeals by special leave dismissed; High Court order upheld; levy of sales tax on appellant under s.14-A for third category transactions confirmed.

key_quotes.text: The section makes the agent liable fictionally as a dealer in the circumstances laid down in the section, viz., that he is acting on behalf of a non-resident person doing business of buying or selling goods in the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains operation of s.14-A deeming provision.

key_quotes.text: No finding on the facts of one case can be applied to the facts of another.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The High Court, in our opinion, was, therefore, right in upholding the levy of the tax from the appellant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Concludes in favour of tax liability.
